title: Step 1 – Project Overview
content:
Welcome to the **Next.js 14 + TypeScript To-Do App Workshop**!

In this hands-on activity, you will progressively build a complete **To-Do List Application** using the App Router. Each step introduces a new concept: project setup, components, state, styling, and deployment — the essence of *Learning by Doing*.

title: Step 2 – Setup Environment
content:
Ensure your system is ready:

1️⃣ Install **Node.js v18+ (LTS)** from [nodejs.org](https://nodejs.org)
2️⃣ Use a modern editor like **VS Code**.
3️⃣ Check your versions:
explain: Always use an LTS (Long-Term Support) version for stability and compatibility.

quiz.question: Which command checks your Node.js version?

title: Step 3 – Create a New Project
content:
Let’s scaffold your project:

Open your terminal and run:
code:
npx create-next-app@latest next-todo --typescript --eslint --app
cd next-todo
npm run dev

quiz.question: What flag activates the App Router when creating a Next.js app?

title: Step 4 – Understand the Structure
content: You should now see this structure:
code:
app/
  layout.tsx
  page.tsx
  globals.css
components/
  TodoList.tsx
explain: The **app/** folder contains your routes and layouts. The **components/** folder will contain reusable UI parts.

quiz.question: Which folder defines page routes in a Next.js App Router project?

title: Step 5 – Create the To-Do List Component
content:
Now let’s build your first **interactive React component** using only **React state** and **Tailwind CSS**. This will give you a working foundation before adding animations and icons later.

Inside the `components` folder, create a new file named **`TodoList.tsx`** and paste:
explain: In this step you learned how to manage a list of items with React’s `useState` hook. You can now add and remove tasks interactively, while Tailwind CSS gives you a clean modern layout.

quiz.question: Which React hook stores the list of tasks?

title: Step 6 – Install Animation and Icon Libraries
content: To make your To-Do List visually stunning and interactive, let’s install **Framer Motion** (for animations) and **Lucide React** (for icons).
explain: Framer Motion provides smooth animations for React components, while Lucide React offers modern, minimalist SVG icons perfect for your UI.

quiz.question: Which library is used for React animations?

title: Step 7 – Build the Professional To-Do List UI
content: Now that dependencies are installed, let’s upgrade your To-Do List with animations, icons, and persistent data using **localStorage**.
explain: You now have a sleek, animated, and persistent To-Do List using **Tailwind CSS**, **Framer Motion**, and **Lucide React** icons. The app automatically saves tasks in localStorage.

quiz.question: Which API is used to save tasks locally in the browser?

quiz.question: Which hook lets you run side effects like saving to localStorage?

title: Step 9 – Deploy and Reflect
content:
You’re done! Deploy by pushing to GitHub and connecting to [Vercel](https://vercel.com).

You now understand the full workflow:
- Scaffold → Code → Style → Persist → Deploy
